subject: Re: [junit] Strange request: examples of "beautiful" test code
msgSnippet: ... I don t know, I still have mixed feelings about this approach.  Although I agree this particular example does read well, it s still extra verbose (e.g. the
messageBody:
On 11/30/06, David Saff <saff@...> wrote:
>
>
> I'll second that. Constraints make a lot of things very nice--I'm
> particularly proud of this, adapted from some GUI testing code:
>
> assertThat(valueOf(button).isEnabled(), eventually(eq(true)));


I don't know, I still have mixed feelings about this approach. Although I
agree this particular example does read well, it's still extra verbose (e.g.
the "eq" statement) and I'm not completely convinced that to a programmer,

assertTrue(valueOf(button).isEnabled())

is that much harder to read.

Anyway, my experience with this kind of literate assertions is that it
scales very poorly as soon as you try to assert more than a simple equality
or a boolean, and in the end, you're probably better off simply writing a
method assertButtonIsEnabled(enabled) which, in my opinion, is the most
readable of all.

--
Cédric
http://testng.org


[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]
